discussion.content: A. 20 is holding read and write locks which blocks the other commands.
It is not D, it wouldn't block access to the table. Its either id 20 or 21

questions.question_text: Which two are true about binary logs used in asynchronous replication? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
A is wrong. Replica pulls from master.

Selected Answer: BE
B. They contain events that describe database changes on the master.

Binary logs in MySQL contain events that describe changes to the data in the master database. These changes can include INSERTs, UPDATEs, DELETEs, and other data modifications.
E. They are pulled from the master to the slave.

In asynchronous replication, the slave server typically pulls the binary logs from the master server. The slave connects to the master and requests the binary log events it needs to replicate changes from the master.
Option A is not entirely accurate because binary logs are not "pushed" from the master to the slave; instead, they are made available on the master for the slave to pull.

Option C and D are incorrect because binary logs do not necessarily contain all queries or administrative commands run on the master; they specifically contain events related to database changes, not all SQL queries or administrative commands.

Selected Answer: BE
Each replica that connects to the source requests a copy of the binary log. That is, it pulls the data from the source, rather than the source pushing the data to the replica. The replica also executes the events from the binary log that it receives.

choices.E: They are pulled from the master to the slave.
choices.B: They contain events that describe database changes on the master.
choices.C: They contain events that describe all queries run on the master.
choices.D: They contain events that describe only administrative commands run on the master.
choices.A: They are pushed from the master to the slave.

choices.E:
SELECT email,passwd FROM members
WHERE email = ‘INSERT INTO members(‘email’,’passwd’) VALUES (‘bob@example.com’, ‘secret’);--‘;
choices.D: SELECT id, name FROM user WHERE id=23 OR id=32 AND 1=1;
choices.F: SELECT user, phone FROM customers WHERE name = ‘\; DROP TABLE users; --‘;
choices.B: SELECT id, name FROM user WHERE user.id=(SELECT members.id FROM members);
choices.A:
SELECT user,passwd FROM members -
WHERE user = ‘?’;INSERT INTO members(‘user’,’passwd’) VALUES (‘bob@example.com’,‘secret’);--‘;
choices.C: SELECT id, name FROM user WHERE id=23 OR id=32 OR 1=1;

questions.question_text: Which two queries are examples of successful SQL injection attacks? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
F only possible if session has all privileges;

Selected Answer: AC
A and C
E and F, the other two don't write to the database. A might be valid. Injection is a query inside another query.

choices.B: It creates a logical backup of all metadata, but contains no table data.
choices.A: It creates a logical backup of all MySQL user accounts.
choices.C: It returns an error because the mysqldump command should have been used.
choices.D: It creates a logical backup of only the users database.

questions.question_text:
You execute this command:
shell> mysqlpump --exclude-databases=% --users
Which statement is true?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The correct answer should be A

Selected Answer: A
The correct answer should be A. It only take the dump of user accounts.

Selected Answer: AE
A and E. See documentation: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/innodb-system-tablespace.html

Selected Answer: EF
InnoDB system tablespace contains the doublewrite buffer and the change buffer.
• Each database (including the mysql system database) has a single directory under the
data directory that contains storage-engine specific data files for the database.
– For example: tablename.ibd for InnoDB, which contains the table data and
metadata

Selected Answer: AE
In previous MySQL versions, the system tablespace contained the InnoDB data dictionary, but in MySQL 8.0, InnoDB stores metadata in the MySQL data dictionary. 
The doublewrite buffer storage area also resided in the system tablespace in previous MySQL releases, but this storage area resides in separate doublewrite files as of MySQL 8.0.201.

comments.content: E is stored in tablespace. Not sure why B isn't correct.

discussion.content: A and B. data directory contains other things. double write now has its own files.
